tit.e: Chokusen wakashu (anthology of Japanese poetry compiled by Imperial command)
tit.cmt: omit explanation because it appears immediately below

sen.j: 勅撰和歌集（ちょくせんわかしゅう）は、天皇や太上天皇の命により編集された歌集のこと。
sen.e: The term "chokusen wakashu" represents an anthology of Japanese poetry complied under order of an emperor or a retired emperor.
sen.cmt: 原文に「太上天皇」とありますが、リンク先の用語と混ざっているようです。ウェブを確認し、「上皇」として訳出いたしました。
sen.e: The term "chokusen wakashu" represents an anthology of Japanese poetry complied under order of an emperor or a retired emperor.
The term "chokusen wakashu" represents an anthology of Japanese poetry complied under order of an emperor or a retired emperor.

sen.j: 古今和歌集（延喜5年（905年）成立）に始まり、新続古今和歌集（永享11年（1439年）成立）までの534年間で、21の勅撰和歌集がある。
sen.e: The first chokusen wakashu was the Kokin Wakashu (Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry), which appeared in 905, and 21 chokusen wakashu had been compiled in total for 534 years until the Shinshoku Kokin Wakashu (New Collection of Ancient and Modern Times Continued) was released in 1439.

sen.e: Starting with the Kokin Wakashu (Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry) (completed in 905) until the Shinshoku Kokin Wakashu (New Continued Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry) (completed in 1439), 21 chokusen wakashu were compiled during the 534 years.

Starting with the Kokin Wakashu (Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry) (completed in 905) until the Shinshoku Kokin Wakashu (New Continued Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry) (completed in 1439), 21 chokusen wakashu were compiled during the 534 years.

sen.j: 総称して「二十一代集」という。
sen.e: These 21 anthologies are generically known as 'Nijuichidai-shu' (the twenty-one collections of Japanese poetry compiled by imperial command).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: These 21 anthologies are commonly known together as 'Nijuichidai-shu' (The Twenty-One Collections of Japanese Poetry).
These 21 anthologies are commonly known together as 'Nijuichidai-shu' (The Twenty-One Collections of Japanese Poetry).

sen.j: このほかに南朝で編纂された新葉和歌集を準勅撰集とする。
sen.e: In addition to the above, the anthology named Shinyo Wakashu (Collection of New Pages), which was compiled by the Southern Court, is regarded as a quasi-imperial anthology.
There is also a quasi-Imperial anthology called Shinyo Wakashu (Collection of New Pages), which was compiled by the Southern Court.

sen.j: また編集時期による分類として、三代集（古今集・ 後撰和歌集・拾遺集）・八代集（下記参照）・十三代集（同）とする。
sen.e: Also, imperial anthologies are classified into three groups by year of compilation: Sandai-shu (which means "three major collections of Japanese poetry," containing the Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry, the Later Collection of Japanese Poetry, and the Collection of Gleanings), Hachidai-shu (which means "eight major collections of Japanese poetry," see below for details), and Jusandai-chu (which means "thirteen major collections of Japanese poetry," see below for details).

Imperial anthologies are classified into three groups according to the year of compilation: Sandai-shu (Three Major Collections of Japanese Poetry) (containing the Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry, the Later Collection of Japanese Poetry, and the Collection of Gleanings), Hachidai-shu (Eight Major Collections of Japanese Poetry) (see below), and Jusandai-shu (Thirteen Major Collections of Japanese Poetry) (see below).
